Lesson Narrative

The mathematical purpose of this lesson is for students to find and interpret the correlation coefficient and to use it to understand the strength of a linear relationship. The term correlation coefficient is introduced and is defined as a number that can be used to determine how well a line models the data. The work of this lesson connects to previous work because students plotted and analyzed residuals to informally assess the fit of linear models. The work of this lesson connects to upcoming work because students will use technology to compute the correlation coefficient and use it to describe the relationship between two variables.

When students sorted scatter plots, they were given the opportunity to analyze representations, statements, and structures closely and make connections. When students take turns with a partner, matching graphs of residuals to scatter plots that display linear models with the correlation coefficient, students trade roles explaining their thinking and listening, providing opportunities to explain their reasoning and critique the reasoning of others.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Match the correlation coefficient to its appropriate scatter plot and linear model.
  • Use the correlation coefficient to determine how well a linear model fits a data set.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Describe the “goodness of fit” of a linear model using the correlation coefficient.
  • Match the correlation coefficient with a scatter plot and linear model.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)

TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

4(A) calculate, using technology, the correlation coefficient between two quantitative variables and interpret this quantity as a measure of the strength of the linear association.

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.


Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 3.4.0: Lesson Overview
  • 3.4.1: Compare Scatter Plots with Linear and Nonlinear Trends
  • 3.4.2: Scatter Plot Differences and Connections to Correlation Coefficient
    • 3.4.2: Self Check
    • 3.4.2: Additional Resources
  • 3.4.3: Matching Correlation Coefficients
    • 3.4.3: Self Check
    • 3.4.3: Additional Resources
  • 3.4.4: Using Correlation Coefficient to Determine Best Fit

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 3.4.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Pre-printed slips, cut from copies of the blackline master for 3.4.2 Card Sort

Required Preparation

Print and cut up slips from the blackline master for the card sort activity. One copy is needed for every group of 2 students.

Lesson Vocabulary 

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

Previous Vocabulary

  • residual

New Vocabulary

  • correlation coefficient
